case_name: Pradeep Lamp Works v. Pradeep Lamp Works Karamchari Sangh and Pradeep Lamp Workers Union

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 482 of 1967

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 482 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated October 13, 1966 of the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, Patna in Reference No. 7 of 1964 pronounced on the November 10, 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated October 13, 1966 of the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, Patna

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated October 13, 1966 of the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, Patna in Reference No. 7 of 1964 pronounced on the November 10, 1966. R. Gokhale, K. B. Rohtagi and S. P. Wad, for the appellant, C. Manchanda, S. S. Khanduja and R. A. Gupta, for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Reference No. 7 of 1964

anchor.surface_text: Patna in Reference No. 7 of 1964 pronounced on the November 10, 1966. R. Gokhale, K. B. Rohtagi and S. P. Wad, for the appellant, C. Manchanda, S. S. Khanduja and R. A. Gupta, for respondent No. 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Dua, J.

facts.text: Award pronounced on November 10, 1966

anchor.surface_text: Reference No. 7 of 1964 pronounced on the November 10, 1966. R. Gokhale, K. B. Rohtagi and S. P. Wad, for the appellant, C. Manchanda, S. S. Khanduja and R. A. Gupta, for respondent No. 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Dua, J. This appeal by special leave is directed against the award of the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, dated October 13, 1966.

facts.text: Strike launched by the workers on the morning of February 27, 1964

anchor.surface_text: On March 20, 1964 the Governor of Bihar referred the following disputes to the Industrial Tribunal Whether the strike launched by the workers on the morning of the 27th February, 1964, was justified ? Whether the lock-out declared by the Management is justified ?

facts.text: Governor of Bihar referred disputes to Industrial Tribunal on March 20, 1964

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the award of the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, dated October 13, 1966. by means of which the workmen of the appellant were held entitled to wages for the period of the lock out beginning with February 28, 1964 and ending with March 22, 1964. On March 20, 1964 the Governor of Bihar referred the following disputes to the Industrial Tribunal

facts.text: Lock-out beginning with February 28, 1964 and ending with March 22, 1964

anchor.surface_text: dated October 13, 1966. by means of which the workmen of the appellant were held entitled to wages for the period of the lock out beginning with February 28, 1964 and ending with March 22, 1964. On March 20, 1964 the Governor of Bihar referred the following disputes to the Industrial Tribunal

facts.text: Tribunal held strike by workmen on February 27, 1964 was not justified

anchor.surface_text: Whether the workmen are entitled to wages for the period of strike and or lock-out On the first point the Tribunal came to the conclusion that the strike by the workmen on February 27, 1964 was not justified.

facts.text: Lock-out declared by Management on February 27, 1964 held justified by Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: the strike by the workmen on February 27, 1964 was not justified. As a result of this conclusion the lock-out declared by the Management on February 27, 1964 was held to be justified but on a consideration of the material placed before the Tribunal no justification for continuing the lock-out on the following days was shown.

facts.text: No justification for continuing lock-out after February 27, 1964

anchor.surface_text: the lock-out declared by the Management on February 27, 1964 was held to be justified but on a consideration of the material placed before the Tribunal no justification for continuing- the lock-out on the following days was shown. On this conclusion the Tribunal decided under point No. 3 that the workmen were entitled to wages for the remaining period of the lock-out.

facts.text: Workmen entitled to wages for remaining period of lock-out per Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: Tribunal no justification for continuing- the lock-out on the following days was shown. On this conclusion the Tribunal decided under point No. 3 that the workmen were entitled to wages for the remaining period of the lock-out. In this Court the learned Advocate for the appellant raised only two points.

facts.text: Appellant conceded finding of fact on strike not open to challenge under Article 136

anchor.surface_text: the lockout by the Management was unjustified after February 27, 1964 and the second submission assailed the decision under point No. 3 awarding to the workmen wages for the period of lock-out between February 28, 1964 and March 22, 1964. On the first point Shri Gokhale very frankly conceded that the finding of fact arrived at by the Tribunal was not open to challenge in the present appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Tribunal proceedings held on September 29, 1966

anchor.surface_text: He referred us to the proceedings of the Tribunal held on September 29, 1966. On that date the Tribunal recorded the following order Parties present.

facts.text: Management represented by Shri Pandey S. Prasad on Sept 29, 1966

anchor.surface_text: Parties present. Management is represented by Shri. Pandey S. Prasad, personal officer and the workmen are represented by Shri Kalika Nandan Singh, Advocate, on behalf of Pradeep Lamp Works Karamchari Sangh and Shri B. B. Karan on behalf of Pradeep Lamp Workers Union.

facts.text: Karamchari Sangh pleaded inability to start evidence on Sept 29, 1966

anchor.surface_text: Hearing on the case is taken up. As the Karamchari Sangh pleaded its inability to start its evidence, the management is called upon to produce its witnesses. The management examines M.W. 1. Trilokinath Rastogi and M.W. 2 Shri R. M. Kahattriya who are discharged after cross-examination.

facts.text: Management examined M.W.1 Trilokinath Rastogi and M.W.2 R.M. Kahattriya on Sept 29

anchor.surface_text: the management is called upon to produce its witnesses. The management examines M.W. 1. Trilokinath Rastogi and M.W. 2 Shri R. M. Kahattriya who are discharged after cross-examination. M.W. 1. proves Exts. A, A-1, B, B/1, B/2 B l for the management.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected management's prayer for adjournment on Sept 29, 1966

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the management prays that the case may be adjourned as it wants to examine more witnesses. The parties should have come ready with all their evidence today. The prayer for adjournment by the management is therefore rejected. Oral evidence on behalf of the management closed.

facts.text: Union examined L.W.1 Krishna Thakur on Sept 29, 1966

anchor.surface_text: Oral evidence on behalf of the management closed. Union examined L.W.l. Krishna Thakur who is discharged, after cross- examination. As it is late, the case is adjourned for tomorrow for further hearing.

facts.text: Case adjourned to next day on Sept 29, 1966

anchor.surface_text: Krishna Thakur who is discharged, after cross- examination. As it is late, the case is adjourned for tomorrow for further hearing. Call for the letter of the Labour Commissioner dated 13-3-64 on partys risk.

facts.text: Appellant made written application for producing witnesses on Sept 29, 1966, disallowed

anchor.surface_text: In this connection our attention was also drawn to a written application made by the appellant to the Tribunal on September 29, 1966 seeking an opportunity for producing the witnesses named therein, but the prayer was disallowed by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Labour Commissioner letter dated 13-3-64 called on party risk

anchor.surface_text: the case is adjourned for tomorrow for further hearing. Call for the letter of the Labour Commissioner dated 13-3-64 on partys risk. The argument strongly pressed on behalf of the appellant was that the Tribunal was wrong in rejecting the appellants prayer for adjournment

facts.text: Strike due to trivial instance of slapping a workman and demand for apology

anchor.surface_text: The, respondents learned Advocate, submitted in reply that the management had been adopting dilatory tactics and there was a very trivial instance of slapping a workman which had led to a demand by the workmen for an apology from the offending party and this had led to the strike and the lock out.

facts.text: Workmen deprived of wages for one day of illegal strike

anchor.surface_text: It was emphasised that for one day when the strike was held to be illegal, the workmen have been deprived of their wages completely. Thereafter they were always willing to work but the management declared a lock out and continued the same with- out any justification.

facts.text: Court finds Tribunal order on adjournment appears arbitrary

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it was incumbent on the Tribunal to apply its mind to the question of apportionment of blame on the two parties and to its effect on the amount of wages to be awarded to the workmen for the period of the lock out after February 28, 1964. The order of the Tribunal ignoring this important aspect is infirm and is difficult to sustain.

facts.text: Court opines apportionment of blame needed for wages after Feb 28, 1964

anchor.surface_text: In so far as the first question in concerned, prima facie, the order of the Tribunal does appear to be somewhat arbitrary and injudicious and it would have been more appropriate exercise of judicial discretion to adjourn the case to the following day for the production of the appellants evidence, if necessary, on payment of costs.

under Article 136 of the Constitution. He, however, contended that the order of the Tribunal in this respect is open to question on the ground that the appellant had been deprived of a reason-able opportunity of adducing evidence in support of its case.

issues.text: Whether the exercise of discretion by the Tribunal in refusing adjournment can be assailed on appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: the question whether or number a party is entitled to an adjournment for producing its evidence is a matter of discretion and the exercise of discretion cannot be assailed on appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The finding of fact arrived at by the Tribunal that the lockout by the Management was unjustified after February 27, 1964 was not open to challenge in the present appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: the lockout by the Management was unjustified after February 27, 1964 and the second submission assailed the decision under point No. 3 awarding to the workmen wages for the period of lock-out between February 28, 1964 and March 22, 1964. On the first point Shri Gokhale very frankly conceded that the finding of fact arrived at by the Tribunal was not open to challenge in the present appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The order of the Tribunal in respect of the justification of the lock-out is open to question on the ground that the appellant had been deprived of a reasonable opportunity of adducing evidence in support of its case

anchor.surface_text: He, however, contended that the order of the Tribunal in this respect is open to question on the ground that the appellant had been deprived of a reason-able opportunity of adducing evidence in support of its case. He referred us to the proceedings of the Tribunal held on September 29, 1966.

arguments.claim: The Tribunal was wrong in rejecting the appellant's prayer for adjournment when it had already given time to the Karamchari Sangh to produce its evidence later

anchor.surface_text: The argument strongly pressed on behalf of the appellant was that the Tribunal was wrong in rejecting the appellants prayer for adjournment when it had already given time to the Karamchari Sangh to produce its evidence later because of its inability to start its evidence in the first instance.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ion of apportionment of blame on the two parties and to its effect on the amount of wages to be awarded to the workmen for the period of the lock out

arguments.court_reasoning: Prima facie arbitrary; better exercise of discretion to adjourn on costs

arguments.claim: The discretion exercised by the Tribunal was arbitrary and contrary to the accepted judicial procedure

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellants argument the discretion exercised by the Tribunil was arbitrary and contrary to the accepted judicial procedure. In this connection our attention was also drawn to a written application

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ion of apportionment of blame on the two parties and to its effect on the amount of wages to be awarded to the workmen for the period of the lock out

arguments.court_reasoning: Order appears somewhat arbitrary and injudicious

arguments.claim: The order of the Tribunal disallowing the prayer for producing witnesses was discriminatory and violative of the recognised standards of judicial impartiality

anchor.surface_text: In this connection our attention was also drawn to a written application made by the appellant to the Tribunal on September 29, 1966 seeking an opportunity for producing the witnesses named therein, but the prayer was disallowed by the Tribunal. The order of the Tribunal disallowing the prayer was described the learned Advocate to be discriminatory and violative of the recognised standards of judicial impartiality.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ion of apportionment of blame on the two parties and to its effect on the amount of wages to be awarded to the workmen for the period of the lock out

arguments.claim: Had the Sangh been compelled to start its evidence, the appellant's oral evidence could not be closed and could be produced the next day

anchor.surface_text: Had the Sangh been compelled to start its evidence, then, so proceeded the argument, the appellants oral evidence could not be closed because the case was adjourned to the following day without concluding the recording of the evidence of the Union and on that day the remaining evidence of the management could be produced in the normal course.

arguments.claim: The parties must be presumed to have been directed by the Tribunal on the previous hearing to come ready with their oral evidence on September 29, 1966

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent Shri Manchanda tried to meet this argument by submitting that the parties must be presumed to have been directed by the Tribunal on the previous hearing to come ready with their oral evidence on September 29, 1966.

arguments.claim: To rebut the presumption of direction to be ready, the appellant should have got printed the previous order adjourning the case to September 29, 1966

anchor.surface_text: To rebut this presumption, argued Shri Manchanda, the appellant should have got printed the previous order adjourning the case to September 29, 1966 for recording the evidence of the parties.

arguments.claim: The question whether a party is entitled to an adjournment for producing its evidence is a matter of discretion and the exercise of discretion cannot be assailed on appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate also submitted that the question whether or not a party is entitled to an adjournment for producing its evidence is a matter of discretion and the exercise of discretion cannot be assailed on appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ion of apportionment of blame on the two parties and to its effect on the amount of wages to be awarded to the workmen for the period of the lock out

arguments.court_reasoning: Discretion exercised arbitrarily, making it assailable

arguments.claim: Full wages could not be awarded to the workmen for the remaining period of the lock-out as blame for the lock-out was apportionable to both parties; normal practice is to award half wages

anchor.surface_text: The second point strongly urged by Shri Gokhale relates to the grant of full wages to the workmen for the remaining period of the lock-out. If the blame for the lock-out was apportionable to both the parties the, according to the submission, full wages could not be awarded.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: as would justify the management to declare the lock-out, more particularly to companytinue it for s

arguments.court_reasoning: Incumbent on Tribunal to apply mind to apportionment; order ignoring this infirm

arguments.claim: In cases where blame attaches to both parties in illegal strike followed by lock-out, loss should be divided half and half (citing India General Navigation case)

anchor.surface_text: In such cases the normal practice, argued the learned Advocate, was to award half of their wages. In support of this submission reference was, to begin with, made to a decision of this Court as India General Navigation and Railway Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: as would justify the management to declare the lock-out, more particularly to companytinue it for s

arguments.claim: Where unjustified strike followed by lock-out that becomes unjustified due to duration, blame apportioned half and half (citing India Marine Service case)

anchor.surface_text: The other decision cited on this point is reported as India Marine Service Private Ltd. v. Their Workmen. At page 583 of the report it was observed thus It is true that the strike was intended to be a token one.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: as would justify the management to declare the lock-out, more particularly to companytinue it for s

arguments.claim: The management had been adopting dilatory tactics and a trivial instance of slapping a workman led to demand for apology, causing strike and lock-out

anchor.surface_text: The, respondents learned Advocate, submitted in reply that the management had been adopting dilatory tactics and there was a very trivial instance of slapping a workman which had led to a demand by the workmen for an apology from the offending party and this had led to the strike and the lock out.

arguments.claim: For one day of illegal strike, workmen deprived of wages completely; thereafter willing to work but management continued lock-out without justification

anchor.surface_text: It was emphasised that for one day when the strike was held to be illegal, the workmen have been deprived of their wages completely. Thereafter they were always willing to work but the management declared a lock out and continued the same without any justification.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: as would justify the management to declare the lock-out, more particularly to companytinue it for s

arguments.claim: Assault on workman not serious enough to justify lock-out, particularly continuation for long duration (citing case)

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate referred us to a pany Ltd. v. Their Employees in support of his submission that the assault on a workman was not a matter of such a serious nature as would justify the management to declare the lock-out, more particularly to continue it for such a long duration.

arguments.claim: It was incumbent on the Tribunal to apply its mind to the question of apportionment of blame on the two parties and its effect on wages for lock-out period after February 28, 1964

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it was incumbent on the Tribunal to apply its mind to the question of apportionment of blame on the two parties and to its effect on the amount of wages to be awarded to the workmen for the period of the lock out after February 28, 1964.

arguments.claim: The Tribunal's order ignoring apportionment of blame is infirm and difficult to sustain

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Tribunal ignoring this important aspect is infirm and is difficult to sustain.

arguments.claim: The order of the Tribunal on adjournment appears somewhat arbitrary and injudicious; more appropriate to adjourn to next day on payment of costs

anchor.surface_text: In so far as the first question in concerned, prima facie, the order of the Tribunal does appear to be somewhat arbitrary and injudicious and it would have been more appropriate exercise of judicial discretion to adjourn the case to the following day for the production of the appellants evidence, if necessary, on payment of costs.

holdings.text: it was incumbent on the Tribunal to apply its mind to the question of apportionment of blame on the two parties and to its effect on the amount of wages to be awarded to the workmen for the period of the lock out after February 28, 1964. The order of the Tribunal ignoring this important aspect is infirm and is difficult to sustain.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it was incumbent on the Tribunal to apply its mind to the question of apportionment of blame on the two parties and to its effect on the amount of wages to be awarded to the workmen for the period of the lock out after February 28, 1964. The order of the Tribunal ignoring this important aspect is infirm and is difficult to sustain.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unjustified strike initiated dispute; lock-out initially justified but continuation unjustified; precedents require apportionment of blame (half wages) when both parties at fault; Tribunal failed to consider this.

holdings.text: prima facie, the order of the Tribunal does appear to be somewhat arbitrary and injudicious and it would have been more appropriate exercise of judicial discretion to adjourn the case to the following day for the production of the appellants evidence, if necessary, on payment of costs.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as the first question in concerned, prima facie, the order of the Tribunal does appear to be somewhat arbitrary and injudicious and it would have been more appropriate exercise of judicial discretion to adjourn the case to the following day for the production of the appellants evidence, if necessary, on payment of costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal rejected adjournment after allowing other party time despite inability; arbitrary exercise of discretion violating natural justice principles of reasonable opportunity to adduce evidence.

holdings.text: Had we decided to remit the case back to the Tribunal for considering the question of the effect of both parties being blame worthy for the lock out on the amount of wages to awarded, we would have perhaps thought it proper also to direct the Tribunal to permit the appellant to adduce evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Had we decided to remit the case back to the Tribunal for considering the question of the effect of both parties being blame worthy for the lock out on the amount of wages to awarded, we would have perhaps thought it proper also to direct the Tribunal to permit the appellant to adduce evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical: If remanding for apportionment, also permit additional evidence due to procedural infirmity.

precedents.cited_proposition: when blame attaches to both parties in an illegal strike situation, loss should be divided half and half, entitling workmen to only half wages for the period
precedents.cited_holding: When the blame attaches to both the parties, we think that they should divide the loss half and half between them

precedents.case_name: India Marine Service Private Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: where unjustified strike followed by lock-out justified initially but continuation unjustified due to long duration, apportion blame between parties roughly half and half for wages

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it was incumbent on the Tribunal to apply its mind to the question of apportionment of blame on the two parties and to its effect on the amount of wages to be awarded to the workmen for the period of the lock out after February 28, 1964.
